natural problem: Five standard six-sided dice are rolled.  We are told there is no three-of-a-kind, but there is a pair of dice that show the same number.  These two dice are set aside, and the other three dice are re-rolled.  What is the probability that after re-rolling these three dice, at least three of the five dice show the same value?
natural solution: There are a total of $6^3=216$ possible sets of dice rolls. If at least one of the re-rolled dice matches the pair we set aside, we will have at least three dice showing the same value. But we will also have three dice showing the same value if all three re-rolled dice come up the same.

Consider the first case. There are five ways for each of the three dice NOT to match the pair, so there are $5^3=125$ ways for NONE of the three dice to match the pair, so there are $216-125=91$ ways for at least one of the three dice to match the pair.

In the second case, we need all three dice to match each other. There are $6$ ways to pick which value the three dice will have. But we have overcounted by $1;$ both of the above cases include the outcome where all five dice match.
So there are $91+6-1 = 96$ ways to have at least three dice match.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes probability :: "real"
assumes h0 : "0 \<le> probability"
and h1 : "probability \<le> 1"
and h2 : "probability = (4 / 9)"
shows  "probability_of_at_least_three_same_values_after_rerolling_three_dice = probability"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Five standard six-sided dice are rolled.  We are told there is no three-of-a-kind, but there is a pair of dice that show the same number.  These two dice are set aside, and the other three dice are re-rolled.  What is the probability that after re-rolling these three dice, at least three of the five dice show the same value? The final Answer is \frac{4}{9}
 ### Proof
 There are a total of $6^3=216$ possible sets of dice rolls. If at least one of the re-rolled dice matches the pair we set aside, we will have at least three dice showing the same value. But we will also have three dice showing the same value if all three re-rolled dice come up the same.
 Consider the first case. There are five ways for each of the three dice NOT to match the pair, so there are $5^3=125$ ways for NONE of the three dice to match the pair, so there are $216-125=91$ ways for at least one of the three dice to match the pair.
 In the second case, we need all three dice to match each other. There are $6$ ways to pick which value the three dice will have. But we have overcounted by $1;$ both of the above cases include the outcome where all five dice match.
 So there are $91+6-1 = 96$ ways to have at least three dice match.
 So, the probability is $$\frac{\text{successful outcomes}}{\text{total outcomes}}=\frac{96}{216}=\boxed{\frac{4}{9}}.$$
 *)

theorem
fixes probability :: "real"
assumes h0 : "0 \<le> probability"
and h1 : "probability \<le> 1"
and h2 : "probability = (4 / 9)"
shows  "probability_of_at_least_three_same_values_after_rerolling_three_dice = probability"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: What is the probability of getting at least three same values after rerolling three dice, if the probability is given as $\frac{4}{9}$? The final answer is $\frac{4}{9}$.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P :: "real \<Rightarrow> real" and dice :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "dice 1 + dice 2 + dice 3 + dice 4 + dice 5 = 1"
and h1 : "\<forall>n. 1 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 6 \<longrightarrow> dice n \<ge> 0"
and h2 : "\<forall>n. 1 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 6 \<longrightarrow> dice n \<le> 1/6"
and h3 : "\<forall>n. 1 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 6 \<longrightarrow> P (dice n) = 1"
and h4 : "\<forall>n m. 1 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 6 \<and> 1 \<le> m \<and> m \<le> 6 \<and> n \<noteq> m \<longrightarrow> P (dice n) * P (dice m) = 0"
and h5 : "\<forall>n. 1 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 6 \<longrightarrow> P (dice n) = (P (dice n))^3"
shows  "sum P {1..6} = 4/9"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Five standard six-sided dice are rolled.  We are told there is no three-of-a-kind, but there is a pair of dice that show the same number.  These two dice are set aside, and the other three dice are re-rolled.  What is the probability that after re-rolling these three dice, at least three of the five dice show the same value? The final Answer is \frac{4}{9}
 ### Proof
 There are a total of $6^3=216$ possible sets of dice rolls. If at least one of the re-rolled dice matches the pair we set aside, we will have at least three dice showing the same value. But we will also have three dice showing the same value if all three re-rolled dice come up the same.
 Consider the first case. There are five ways for each of the three dice NOT to match the pair, so there are $5^3=125$ ways for NONE of the three dice to match the pair, so there are $216-125=91$ ways for at least one of the three dice to match the pair.
 In the second case, we need all three dice to match each other. There are $6$ ways to pick which value the three dice will have. But we have overcounted by $1;$ both of the above cases include the outcome where all five dice match.
 So there are $91+6-1 = 96$ ways to have at least three dice match.
 So, the probability is $$\frac{\text{successful outcomes}}{\text{total outcomes}}=\frac{96}{216}=\boxed{\frac{4}{9}}.$$
 *)

theorem
fixes P :: "real \<Rightarrow> real" and dice :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "dice 1 + dice 2 + dice 3 + dice 4 + dice 5 = 1"
and h1 : "\<forall>n. 1 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 6 \<longrightarrow> dice n \<ge> 0"
and h2 : "\<forall>n. 1 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 6 \<longrightarrow> dice n \<le> 1/6"
and h3 : "\<forall>n. 1 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 6 \<longrightarrow> P (dice n) = 1"
and h4 : "\<forall>n m. 1 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 6 \<and> 1 \<le> m \<and> m \<le> 6 \<and> n \<noteq> m \<longrightarrow> P (dice n) * P (dice m) = 0"
and h5 : "\<forall>n. 1 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 6 \<longrightarrow> P (dice n) = (P (dice n))^3"
shows  "sum P {1..6} = 4/9"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: A fair dice has six faces numbered 1 to 6, and each face has a probability of 1/6 to show up. Let $P(x)$ be a function that takes the probability of a face showing up as its input. It is given that the sum of the probabilities of the five faces is 1, and for each face, $P(x) = 1$ and $P(x) = P(x)^3$. Furthermore, for any two different faces, the product of their $P(x)$ values is 0. Find the sum of $P(x)$ for all faces of the dice. The final answer is $\frac{4}{9}$.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P1 P2 P3 :: real
assumes h0 : "0 \<le> P1"
and h1 : "P1 \<le> 1"
and h2 : "0 \<le> P2"
and h3 : "P2 \<le> 1"
and h4 : "0 \<le> P3"
and h5 : "P3 \<le> 1"
and h6 : "P1 = 1 - (1/6)^3 - (5/6)^3"
and h7 : "P2 = 1 - (1/6)^2 - (5/6)^2"
and h8 : "P3 = P1 * P2"
shows  "P3 = 4/9"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Five standard six-sided dice are rolled.  We are told there is no three-of-a-kind, but there is a pair of dice that show the same number.  These two dice are set aside, and the other three dice are re-rolled.  What is the probability that after re-rolling these three dice, at least three of the five dice show the same value? The final Answer is \frac{4}{9}
 ### Proof
 There are a total of $6^3=216$ possible sets of dice rolls. If at least one of the re-rolled dice matches the pair we set aside, we will have at least three dice showing the same value. But we will also have three dice showing the same value if all three re-rolled dice come up the same.
 Consider the first case. There are five ways for each of the three dice NOT to match the pair, so there are $5^3=125$ ways for NONE of the three dice to match the pair, so there are $216-125=91$ ways for at least one of the three dice to match the pair.
 In the second case, we need all three dice to match each other. There are $6$ ways to pick which value the three dice will have. But we have overcounted by $1;$ both of the above cases include the outcome where all five dice match.
 So there are $91+6-1 = 96$ ways to have at least three dice match.
 So, the probability is $$\frac{\text{successful outcomes}}{\text{total outcomes}}=\frac{96}{216}=\boxed{\frac{4}{9}}.$$
 *)

theorem
fixes P1 P2 P3 :: real
assumes h0 : "0 \<le> P1"
and h1 : "P1 \<le> 1"
and h2 : "0 \<le> P2"
and h3 : "P2 \<le> 1"
and h4 : "0 \<le> P3"
and h5 : "P3 \<le> 1"
and h6 : "P1 = 1 - (1/6)^3 - (5/6)^3"
and h7 : "P2 = 1 - (1/6)^2 - (5/6)^2"
and h8 : "P3 = P1 * P2"
shows  "P3 = 4/9"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: Suppose three probabilities $P1$, $P2$, and $P3$ are given. All of them are non-negative and less than or equal to 1. $P1$ is defined as $1 - (\frac{1}{6})^3 - (\frac{5}{6})^3$, $P2$ is defined as $1 - (\frac{1}{6})^2 - (\frac{5}{6})^2$, and $P3$ is the product of $P1$ and $P2$. Find the value of $P3$. The final answer is $\frac{4}{9}$.

a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Five standard six-sided dice are rolled.  We are told there is no three-of-a-kind, but there is a pair of dice that show the same number.  These two dice are set aside, and the other three dice are re-rolled.  What is the probability that after re-rolling these three dice, at least three of the five dice show the same value? The final Answer is \frac{4}{9}
 ### Proof
 There are a total of $6^3=216$ possible sets of dice rolls. If at least one of the re-rolled dice matches the pair we set aside, we will have at least three dice showing the same value. But we will also have three dice showing the same value if all three re-rolled dice come up the same.
 Consider the first case. There are five ways for each of the three dice NOT to match the pair, so there are $5^3=125$ ways for NONE of the three dice to match the pair, so there are $216-125=91$ ways for at least one of the three dice to match the pair.
 In the second case, we need all three dice to match each other. There are $6$ ways to pick which value the three dice will have. But we have overcounted by $1;$ both of the above cases include the outcome where all five dice match.
 So there are $91+6-1 = 96$ ways to have at least three dice match.
 So, the probability is $$\frac{\text{successful outcomes}}{\text{total outcomes}}=\frac{96}{216}=\boxed{\frac{4}{9}}.$$
 *)

theorem
fixes P :: "real"
assumes h0 : "P = (\<Sum>x\<in>{1..6}. (5 choose 2) * (1/6)^2 * (1/6)^3 * (1 - (1/6))^3) * (\<Sum>y\<in>{1..6}. (3 choose 2) * (1/6)^2 * (1/6)^1 * (1 - (1/6))^1)"
shows  "P = 4/9"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem:
Compute the probability $P$ that can be expressed as the product of the following two sums: 
1. The sum for all $x$ in the range of 1 to 6 of ${5 \choose 2}(1/6)^2(1/6)^3(1-(1/6))^3$.
2. The sum for all $y$ in the range of 1 to 6 of ${3 \choose 2}(1/6)^2(1/6)^1(1-(1/6))^1$.

The final answer is $\frac{4}{9}$.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P :: "rat"
assumes h0 : "P = 4 / 9"
shows  "P = (GREATEST p. \<exists> n m k l. n \<ge> 0 \<and> m \<ge> 0 \<and> k \<ge> 0 \<and> l \<ge> 0 \<and> n + m + k + l = 5 \<and> n \<noteq> 3 \<and> p = (n / 6) * (m / 6) * (k / 6) * (l / 6))"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Five standard six-sided dice are rolled.  We are told there is no three-of-a-kind, but there is a pair of dice that show the same number.  These two dice are set aside, and the other three dice are re-rolled.  What is the probability that after re-rolling these three dice, at least three of the five dice show the same value? The final Answer is \frac{4}{9}
 ### Proof
 There are a total of $6^3=216$ possible sets of dice rolls. If at least one of the re-rolled dice matches the pair we set aside, we will have at least three dice showing the same value. But we will also have three dice showing the same value if all three re-rolled dice come up the same.
 Consider the first case. There are five ways for each of the three dice NOT to match the pair, so there are $5^3=125$ ways for NONE of the three dice to match the pair, so there are $216-125=91$ ways for at least one of the three dice to match the pair.
 In the second case, we need all three dice to match each other. There are $6$ ways to pick which value the three dice will have. But we have overcounted by $1;$ both of the above cases include the outcome where all five dice match.
 So there are $91+6-1 = 96$ ways to have at least three dice match.
 So, the probability is $$\frac{\text{successful outcomes}}{\text{total outcomes}}=\frac{96}{216}=\boxed{\frac{4}{9}}.$$
 *)

theorem
fixes P :: "rat"
assumes h0 : "P = 4 / 9"
shows  "P = (GREATEST p. \<exists> n m k l. n \<ge> 0 \<and> m \<ge> 0 \<and> k \<ge> 0 \<and> l \<ge> 0 \<and> n + m + k + l = 5 \<and> n \<noteq> 3 \<and> p = (n / 6) * (m / 6) * (k / 6) * (l / 6))"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: Find the greatest value of $P$ that can be obtained by multiplying the probabilities of four non-negative integers $n, m, k, l$ with the constraint that $n + m + k + l = 5$ and $n \neq 3$. Each probability is calculated as the ratio of the integer to 6 (e.g., $P_n = \frac{n}{6}$, $P_m = \frac{m}{6}$, and so on). The final answer is $\frac{4}{9}$.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes prob :: "real"
assumes h0 : "prob = (\<Sum>i\<in>{1..6}. (\<Sum>j\<in>{1..6}. (if i = j then 0 else (1/6)*(1/6)*(1/6)*(1/6)*(1/6) * (if i = j then 1 else 0))))"
and h1 : "prob = (\<Sum>i\<in>{1..6}. (\<Sum>j\<in>{1..6}. (if i = j then 0 else (1/6)*(1/6)*(1/6)*(1/6)*(1/6) * (\<Sum>k\<in>{1..6}. (if k = i \<or> k = j then 0 else (1/6)*(1/6)*(1/6))))))"
shows  "prob = 4 / 9"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Five standard six-sided dice are rolled.  We are told there is no three-of-a-kind, but there is a pair of dice that show the same number.  These two dice are set aside, and the other three dice are re-rolled.  What is the probability that after re-rolling these three dice, at least three of the five dice show the same value? The final Answer is \frac{4}{9}
 ### Proof
 There are a total of $6^3=216$ possible sets of dice rolls. If at least one of the re-rolled dice matches the pair we set aside, we will have at least three dice showing the same value. But we will also have three dice showing the same value if all three re-rolled dice come up the same.
 Consider the first case. There are five ways for each of the three dice NOT to match the pair, so there are $5^3=125$ ways for NONE of the three dice to match the pair, so there are $216-125=91$ ways for at least one of the three dice to match the pair.
 In the second case, we need all three dice to match each other. There are $6$ ways to pick which value the three dice will have. But we have overcounted by $1;$ both of the above cases include the outcome where all five dice match.
 So there are $91+6-1 = 96$ ways to have at least three dice match.
 So, the probability is $$\frac{\text{successful outcomes}}{\text{total outcomes}}=\frac{96}{216}=\boxed{\frac{4}{9}}.$$
 *)

theorem
fixes prob :: "real"
assumes h0 : "prob = (\<Sum>i\<in>{1..6}. (\<Sum>j\<in>{1..6}. (if i = j then 0 else (1/6)*(1/6)*(1/6)*(1/6)*(1/6) * (if i = j then 1 else 0))))"
and h1 : "prob = (\<Sum>i\<in>{1..6}. (\<Sum>j\<in>{1..6}. (if i = j then 0 else (1/6)*(1/6)*(1/6)*(1/6)*(1/6) * (\<Sum>k\<in>{1..6}. (if k = i \<or> k = j then 0 else (1/6)*(1/6)*(1/6))))))"
shows  "prob = 4 / 9"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: A fair six-sided die is rolled three times. What is the probability that no two of the rolls are the same? The final answer is $\frac{4}{9}$.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P :: "real set"
assumes h0 : "finite P"
and h1 : "card P = 6"
and h2 : "P = {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6}"
and h3 : "events_independent P P P"
shows  "probability (at_least_three_same_value P) = 4 / 9"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Five standard six-sided dice are rolled.  We are told there is no three-of-a-kind, but there is a pair of dice that show the same number.  These two dice are set aside, and the other three dice are re-rolled.  What is the probability that after re-rolling these three dice, at least three of the five dice show the same value? The final Answer is \frac{4}{9}
 ### Proof
 There are a total of $6^3=216$ possible sets of dice rolls. If at least one of the re-rolled dice matches the pair we set aside, we will have at least three dice showing the same value. But we will also have three dice showing the same value if all three re-rolled dice come up the same.
 Consider the first case. There are five ways for each of the three dice NOT to match the pair, so there are $5^3=125$ ways for NONE of the three dice to match the pair, so there are $216-125=91$ ways for at least one of the three dice to match the pair.
 In the second case, we need all three dice to match each other. There are $6$ ways to pick which value the three dice will have. But we have overcounted by $1;$ both of the above cases include the outcome where all five dice match.
 So there are $91+6-1 = 96$ ways to have at least three dice match.
 So, the probability is $$\frac{\text{successful outcomes}}{\text{total outcomes}}=\frac{96}{216}=\boxed{\frac{4}{9}}.$$
 *)

theorem
fixes P :: "real set"
assumes h0 : "finite P"
and h1 : "card P = 6"
and h2 : "P = {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6}"
and h3 : "events_independent P P P"
shows  "probability (at_least_three_same_value P) = 4 / 9"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: In a set P containing six distinct numbers {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6}, find the probability of selecting three numbers with at least three of them having the same value, assuming that the events of selecting these numbers are independent. The final answer is $\frac{4}{9}$.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P1 P2 :: "real"
assumes h0 : "0 \<le> P1"
and h1 : "P1 \<le> 1"
and h2 : "0 \<le> P2"
and h3 : "P2 \<le> 1"
and h4 : "P1 = probability of no three-of-a-kind and a pair in the first roll"
and h5 : "P2 = probability of at least three of the five dice showing the same value after re-rolling three dice"
shows  "P2 = 4 / 9"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Five standard six-sided dice are rolled.  We are told there is no three-of-a-kind, but there is a pair of dice that show the same number.  These two dice are set aside, and the other three dice are re-rolled.  What is the probability that after re-rolling these three dice, at least three of the five dice show the same value? The final Answer is \frac{4}{9}
 ### Proof
 There are a total of $6^3=216$ possible sets of dice rolls. If at least one of the re-rolled dice matches the pair we set aside, we will have at least three dice showing the same value. But we will also have three dice showing the same value if all three re-rolled dice come up the same.

 In the second case, we need all three dice to match each other. There are $6$ ways to pick which value the three dice will have. But we have overcounted by $1;$ both of the above cases include the outcome where all five dice match.
 So there are $91+6-1 = 96$ ways to have at least three dice match.
 So, the probability is $$\frac{\text{successful outcomes}}{\text{total outcomes}}=\frac{96}{216}=\boxed{\frac{4}{9}}.$$
 *)

theorem
fixes P1 P2 :: "real"
assumes h0 : "0 \<le> P1"
and h1 : "P1 \<le> 1"
and h2 : "0 \<le> P2"
and h3 : "P2 \<le> 1"
and h4 : "P1 = probability of no three-of-a-kind and a pair in the first roll"
and h5 : "P2 = probability of at least three of the five dice showing the same value after re-rolling three dice"
shows  "P2 = 4 / 9"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: In a dice game, the probability of not getting a three-of-a-kind and a pair in the first roll is $P1$, and the probability of at least three of the five dice showing the same value after re-rolling three dice is $P2$. Given that $0 \le P1 \le 1$ and $0 \le P2 \le 1$, find the value of $P2$ if $P2 = \frac{4}{9}$.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes prob :: "rat"
assumes h0 : "prob = (\<Sum> i \<in> {1..6}. (1/6)^2 * (1/6) * (3/6)^2 * (1/6) * (5/6)^2 * (binomial 5 2))"
and h1 : "prob = 4 / 9"
shows  "prob = 4 / 9"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Five standard six-sided dice are rolled.  We are told there is no three-of-a-kind, but there is a pair of dice that show the same number.  These two dice are set aside, and the other three dice are re-rolled.  What is the probability that after re-rolling these three dice, at least three of the five dice show the same value? The final Answer is \frac{4}{9}
 ### Proof
 There are a total of $6^3=216$ possible sets of dice rolls. If at least one of the re-rolled dice matches the pair we set aside, we will have at least three dice showing the same value. But we will also have three dice showing the same value if all three re-rolled dice come up the same.
 Consider the first case. There are five ways for each of the three dice NOT to match the pair, so there are $5^3=125$ ways for NONE of the three dice to match the pair, so there are $216-125=91$ ways for at least one of the three dice to match the pair.
 In the second case, we need all three dice to match each other. There are $6$ ways to pick which value the three dice will have. But we have overcounted by $1;$ both of the above cases include the outcome where all five dice match.
 So there are $91+6-1 = 96$ ways to have at least three dice match.
 So, the probability is $$\frac{\text{successful outcomes}}{\text{total outcomes}}=\frac{96}{216}=\boxed{\frac{4}{9}}.$$
 *)

theorem
fixes prob :: "rat"
assumes h0 : "prob = (\<Sum> i \<in> {1..6}. (1/6)^2 * (1/6) * (3/6)^2 * (1/6) * (5/6)^2 * (binomial 5 2))"
and h1 : "prob = 4 / 9"
shows  "prob = 4 / 9"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: Determine the probability of the following event: In a sequence of 6 rolls of a fair six-sided die, exactly two of the rolls result in a 1. The probability of this event occurring is $\frac{4}{9}$.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P_initial P_final :: real
assumes h0 : "P_initial = 5 / 6 * 4 / 6 * 3 / 6 * 2 / 6"
and h1 : "P_final = (1 / 6) * (3 / 6) * (2 / 6)"
and h2 : "P_initial * P_final = 4 / 9"
shows  "4 / 9 = P_initial * P_final"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Five standard six-sided dice are rolled.  We are told there is no three-of-a-kind, but there is a pair of dice that show the same number.  These two dice are set aside, and the other three dice are re-rolled.  What is the probability that after re-rolling these three dice, at least three of the five dice show the same value? The final Answer is \frac{4}{9}
 ### Proof
 There are a total of $6^3=216$ possible sets of dice rolls. If at least one of the re-rolled dice matches the pair we set aside, we will have at least three dice showing the same value. But we will also have three dice showing the same value if all three re-rolled dice come up the same.
 Consider the first case. There are five ways for each of the three dice NOT to match the pair, so there are $5^3=125$ ways for NONE of the three dice to match the pair, so there are $216-125=91$ ways for at least one of the three dice to match the pair.
 In the second case, we need all three dice to match each other. There are $6$ ways to pick which value the three dice will have. But we have overcounted by $1;$ both of the above cases include the outcome where all five dice match.
 So there are $91+6-1 = 96$ ways to have at least three dice match.
 So, the probability is $$\frac{\text{successful outcomes}}{\text{total outcomes}}=\frac{96}{216}=\boxed{\frac{4}{9}}.$$
 *)

theorem
fixes P_initial P_final :: real
assumes h0 : "P_initial = 5 / 6 * 4 / 6 * 3 / 6 * 2 / 6"
and h1 : "P_final = (1 / 6) * (3 / 6) * (2 / 6)"
and h2 : "P_initial * P_final = 4 / 9"
shows  "4 / 9 = P_initial * P_final"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: If the initial probability is given by the product $\frac{5}{6} \cdot \frac{4}{6} \cdot \frac{3}{6} \cdot \frac{2}{6}$ and the final probability is given by the product $\frac{1}{6} \cdot \frac{3}{6} \cdot \frac{2}{6}$, find the product of the initial and final probabilities. The final answer is $\frac{4}{9}$.
